description: From Middle French confiner, from confins, from Medieval Latin confines, from Latin confinium, from confīnis.

entries.meaning: (chiefly in the plural) A boundary or limit.

examples: She says for you to bring her a slice of cake,A bottle of the best wine,And not to forget the fair young ladyThat did release you from close confine.

verbs.description: confine (third-person singular simple present confines, present participle confining, simple past and past participle confined)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To have a common boundary with; to border on. [16th–19th c.]
examples: ‘Why, Sir, to be sure, such parts of Sclavonia as confine with Germany, will borrow German words; and such parts as confine with Tartary will borrow Tartar words.’

entries.meaning: (transitive) To restrict (someone or something) to a particular scope or area; to keep in or within certain bounds. [from 17th c.]
examples: He is to confine himself to the compass of numbers and the slavery of rhyme.
